page.title: 18Brownsea Nature Trail
page.content: The whole of the North-east section of Brownsea is normally closed to the public in order to protect wild-life. However a 1\ hour guided tour of the {Nature Reserve}takes place every afternoon at 14.45 hours. About 6000 people a year go on this nature trail. On the afternoon of Sunday 14th. July 1985 21 adults and 6 children accompanied the guide to see woodland, marsh, a salt-water lagoon and two lakes, which provide a sanctuary for ducks, geese and waders, as well as herons, black-headed gulls and terns. Dogs are not allowed on the island, in case they attack the birds. There is also the hazard of fire. The last great blaze on Browsea was in 1934 when two-thirds of the island was ravaged so there is now a fire-tower at a vantage point in the middle of the island.
